title: The Altar of Witness
shortSummary: Joshua 22 recounts the departure of the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh back to their allotted lands east of the Jordan River after helping their brethren conquer Canaan. A misunderstanding arises when these tribes build a large altar by the Jordan, causing alarm among the other Israelites, but the situation is peacefully resolved through dialogue and clarification of their true intent.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Conquest and settlement of Canaan under Joshua's leadership

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who commands the eastern tribes to return to their land and blesses them before their departure.

keyCharacters.name: Phinehas
keyCharacters.description: Son of Eleazar the priest, sent as a representative to confront the eastern tribes about the altar and later confirms their innocence.

keyCharacters.name: The children of Reuben, Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh
keyCharacters.description: The eastern tribes who built the altar by the Jordan and clarify their purpose to avoid rebellion against God.

definitions.definition: A structure built for making sacrifices or offerings to God, symbolizing worship and covenant relationship.
A command or instruction given by God or a leader, often carrying moral or covenantal weight.
A sin or offense against God’s law, often implying rebellion or disobedience.
A type of sacrifice in the Old Testament expressing fellowship and gratitude toward God.

outline.heading: Joshua Sends the Eastern Tribes Home
outline.description: Joshua commends the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh for their faithfulness and instructs them to return to their lands east of the Jordan, blessing them and encouraging obedience to God's law.

outline.heading: The Altar Built by the Jordan
outline.description: Upon reaching the Jordan border, the eastern tribes build a large altar, which alarms the rest of Israel who fear it signifies rebellion against God.

outline.heading: Israel’s Response and Confrontation
outline.description: The western tribes send Phinehas and leaders to confront the eastern tribes, accusing them of trespassing against God by building an unauthorized altar.

outline.heading: Explanation and Reconciliation
outline.description: The eastern tribes explain the altar’s purpose as a witness to future generations, not for sacrifices, but to maintain unity and shared worship of the LORD, which satisfies the leaders.

outline.heading: Peace Restored and Naming of the Altar
outline.description: Phinehas and the leaders accept the explanation, peace is restored, and the altar is named Ed, meaning 'witness,' symbolizing the covenant unity between the tribes.

application: Obey God’s commands wholeheartedly as the eastern tribes did, demonstrating faithfulness in all areas of life.
Seek peaceful resolution through communication and understanding when misunderstandings arise within the body of Christ.
Remember the importance of maintaining unity among believers by clarifying intentions and avoiding unnecessary division.
Use tangible reminders, like the altar of witness, to encourage future generations to remain faithful to God.

keyVerses.text: But take diligent heed to do the commandment and the law, which Moses the servant of the LORD charged you, to love the LORD your God, and to walk in all his ways, and to keep his commandments, and to cleave unto him, and to serve him with all your heart and with all your soul.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the call to wholehearted obedience and love for God as foundational to the tribes’ faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: God forbid that we should rebel against the LORD, and turn this day from following the LORD, to build an altar for burnt offerings, for meat offerings, or for sacrifices, beside the altar of the LORD our God that is before his tabernacle.
keyVerses.significance: This verse clarifies the eastern tribes’ true intent, emphasizing their loyalty and rejection of rebellion against God.

keyVerses.text: And the children of Reuben and the children of Gad called the altar Ed: for it shall be a witness between us that the LORD is God.
keyVerses.significance: The naming of the altar as 'Ed' symbolizes the covenant witness and unity among the tribes under God.
